_exec_summary.SummaryText:
General Executive Summary for Laredo Products Terminal
We at the NuStar - Laredo Products Terminal are strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The NuStar Laredo Products Terminal adheres to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  NuStar carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. NuStar personnel are trained to respond to minor incidents; however, if response is unsafe for NuStar personnel or the event is a major incident/emergency, the City of Laredo Fire Department is notified and asked to respond.  


Facility Description
Our facility?s primary activities encompass the storage and sale of motor fuel.  The facility includes 2 butane/gasoline mix bullet tanks and one ethyl mercaptan bullet tank.  Butane, which is used as a buffer between gasoline and propane pipeline shipments, is present at the facility above the threshold quantity.  Ethyl mercaptan, which is added to the pipeline to odorize propane before it reaches the next terminal, is also held above the threshold quantity.


Worst-case and Alternative Worst Case Scenarios
To evaluate the worst-case and alternative worst-case scenarios, we have used the EPA?s RMT*Comp program.  The following paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios.

The worst-case release scenario involves a catastrophic release from one butane/gasoline bullet tank.  In this scenario the flammable mixture is released from a bullet tank without consideration for emergency shutdown valves or operator action.  The tank is assumed to be 80% fu

ll (administrative controls limit the tank capacity to 80%) and that the entire quantity is released as a vapor.  The vapor then finds an ignition source, with ten percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud explosion.  Using RMP*comp, the calculated distance to the 1 psi endpoint would have offsite impacts.

The alternative release scenario involves a catastrophic release of the flammable mixture due to a damaged pipe leading to truck loading.  This release is assumed to result in a Vapor Cloud Explosion.  The release is controlled by active mitigation measures that include Emergency Shutoff Valves.  After comparing the effects of fire and overpressure, the vapor cloud explosion scenario was chosen as the worst scenario.  Using RMP*comp, the calculated distance to the flammable endpoint of 1 psi overpressure would involve offsite impacts. 


The General Accident Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps 
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the OSHA PSM standard as well as the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  


Five-year Accident History
NuStar Laredo Products Terminal has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during this period.


Emergency Response Program
NuStar Laredo Products Terminal carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking pla

ce within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Historical developments and findings from our facilities across the country have resulted in the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program company wide.  Monthly safety training, operator training and certification are some of the major programs we use to improve safety at our facility.  These programs are currently implemented and changes are continuous.
